The effect of La incorporation on the catalytic performance of Cu–CeO2 for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was investigated. The increase of the CeO2 lattice constant and shift in the F2g band from Raman spectroscopy confirmed La incorporation into the CeO2 lattice. The La atomic percent of ≤ 19 % was the upper limit for the amount of La incorporated fully into the CeO2 lattice without any phase segregation. XPS results of Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ assumed to have full La incorporation, showed a maximum concentration of oxygen vacancies that facilitated CO2 adsorption and conversion to methanol. The lattice fringes from HRTEM and lattice expansion confirmed that Cu was located on the catalyst surface for the synthesized catalysts. Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ showed an improvement in the methanol space-time yield when the temperature was increased from 260 °C to 280 °C, in contrast to the catalysts with excess La on the surface. The descriptors for the methanol production were the availability of oxygen vacancies and the metal-metal oxide interaction (Cu–CexLa1−xO2-δ and Cu–La2O2CO3). The smaller metallic Cu crystallite size for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ suggested increased interactions between Cu0 and the CexLa1−xO2-δ support, which was conducive for methanol formation. The highest performance of Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ at a higher temperature of 280 °C and pressure of 50 bar with a methanol space-time yield of 55.2 gCH3OH.kgcatal.h−1 was attributed to the excellent thermal stability of the formed CexLa1−xO2-δ solid solution support interacting with Cu which prevented sintering. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol synthesis Copper-ceria CO2 hydrogenation Lanthanum Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Copper-based catalysts are widely used in CO2 and CO hydrogenation to produce methanol [1–3]. Sintering and crystallization of Cu at relatively high operating temperatures due to excessive water being formed via the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction that occurs concomitantly with the methanol synthesis reaction is a challenge. This results in a decrease in the active surface area and consequently catalytic activity, which increases operational costs as it necessitates the complete replacement or regeneration of the catalyst for industrial-scale processes. To circumvent these issues, it becomes crucial to pair Cu with a support or a host that is robust and thermally stable within a wide temperature range of operation. Impressive catalytic performances have previously been demonstrated by Cu/CeO2 [4,5] and Cu/La2O2CO3 [6]. Doping CeO2 with La can improve thermal stability, improve Ce4+ to Ce3+ reduction and reduce the particle size of CeO2 [7,8]. Oxygen vacancies were created when an aliovalent cation such as Gd3+, La3+ or Sm3+ was incorporated into CeO2 to retain a neutral charge [9,10]. Lanthanum has previously shown high efficiency in promoting Ce4+ to Ce3+ reduction compared to other cations such as Mn, Y and Gd [11]. The presence of the dopant such as La in the CeO2 structure is also beneficial for the reduction of other metals such as Cu in the case of the CuCeO2 catalytic system that is effective in reactions such as preferential oxidation [12], water gas shift reaction [13] and methanol synthesis from CO2 [8,14]. Recently, Ji et al. [15] reported that LaOx favours CO2 activation by forming carbon intermediates species and improved Cu dispersion when the CuZnOLa2O3 catalyst was evaluated in methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation. The reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction that occurs in parallel to methanol formation from CO2 hinders the efficiency of the methanol synthesis catalyst. Previously, it has been demonstrated that adding lanthanum as a dopant to CuOCeO2 suppresses CO selectivity in methanol steam reforming (SRM) [16]. Guo et al. [17] demonstrated that introducing La as a promoter for Cu/ZrO2 promotes the hydrogenation of CO2 to the formate intermediate while simultaneously inhibiting the formation of CO as a by-product. When a foreign metal is incorporated into the structure of the host, for example, CeO2, without any phase segregation, it was shown to enhance the thermal stability of the catalyst significantly [18]. This study investigated the effect of La incorporation on the structural properties of CuCeO2 prepared by solution combustion synthesis (SCS), viz. basicity, oxygen vacancies, Cu surface composition and the interaction between Cu and CeO2. The influence of the above-mentioned physicochemical properties on methanol formation from CO2 hydrogenation was critically evaluated and rationalized. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The solution combustion synthesis (SCS) method [19] was used to prepare the catalysts. In a typical synthesis, Cu(NO3)22·5H2O (2.3 g), (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 (8.2 g), La(NO3)3xH2O (4.9 g), and urea-N2COH4 (7.0 g) were dissolved together in 40 mL of deionised water in a borosilicate vessel. Urea was the only fuel used for all syntheses in this study. The solution was stirred in a hotplate without heat at 500 rpm to dissolve the precursors fully. The solution was then placed in a muffle furnace, and the temperature ramped up to 80 °C at a ramp rate of 0.7 °C min−1 and held for 2 h. Thereafter, the temperature was ramped up from 80 °C to 500 °C at 2 °C min−1 and held for 4 h. The resulting catalyst had Cu, Ce and La atomic percentage of 25, 37.5 and 37.5 at.%, respectively. This catalyst was denoted as Cu0.25La0.375Ce0.375O2-δ. Other catalysts were synthesised using the same procedure outlined above, except for the variation of the amounts of Ce and La precursor. The copper content was kept constant at 25 at.% for all the catalysts. The other catalysts were labelled as Cu0.25La0.75Ox, Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, and Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ. CeO2 and LaOx were synthesised by the same catalyst synthesis procedure and labelled CeO2 S and LaOx S, respectively. The fuel-to-oxidiser ratio (ɸ) was kept at 1 to obtain stoichiometric catalysts. 2.2 Characterisation Powder XRD was using an Advanced D8 instrument with a Cu (Kα = 1.5406 Å) radiation source. The catalysts were scanned in the 20° to 90° 2θ range with a step size of 0.02 °. The Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)) was used to calculate the crystallite size of CeO2 using the (111) peak at 28.7°. The microstrain of CeO2 was approximated by the Williamson–Hall method, as reported elsewhere [20]. (1) τ = K × λ β F W H M cos θ Eq. (2) was used to calculate the lattice constant (a) of CeO2. (2) a ( Ce O 2 ) = d h k l × ( h 2 + k 2 + l 2 ) The BET surface area measurements were done on the Tristar II 3020 instrument at −196 °C. Prior to the analysis, the catalysts were degassed for 8 h at 200 °C with N2 flow. The BJH method was used for pore volume and pore diameter determination. The reported BET surface area values were quoted within the P/P0 range of 0.3–0.5. ICP-OES analysis was done using a PerkinElmer OPTIMA instrument. The catalysts were digested with 98 % H2SO4 with a small amount of double distilled water. Raman spectroscopy was done on a Renishaw inVia Raman instrument equipped with a microscope. A wavelength of 514 nm and an exposure time of 30 s was used. The TGA-DSC of the catalysts was done using the TA-SDT Q600 instrument. The temperature was ramped from 30 °C to 1000 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 under N2 with a flow rate of 20 mL min−1. The Autochem II 2920 instrument was used for H2-TPR. 50 mg of catalyst was packed between two layers of quartz wool. A 5 % H2/Ar gas with a flowrate of 30 mL min−1 was used for the reduction, and the temperature was ramped from 80 °C to 800 °C at 10 °C min−1. The hydrogen consumption was monitored with the TCD detector. CO2-TPD and H2-TPD were done on the same instrument used for H2-TPR. For the TPD analyses, 60 mg of the catalyst was packed between the two layers of quartz wool. For CO2-TPD and H2-TPD, the catalysts were first reduced for 2 h with 5 % H2/Ar with a flowrate of 30 mL min−1 at 300 °C. For CO2-TPD, the catalyst was saturated with pure CO2 at 40 °C for 1 h, followed by He flow for another 1 h to remove any physisorbed water. The flowrate for CO2 and He was also 30 mL min−1. The temperature was then increased to 800 °C at 10 °C min−1 under He flow. A TCD detector was used to monitor the amount of CO2 desorbed. For H2-TPD, the catalyst was saturated with 5 % H2/Ar for 1 h, and a similar procedure as for the CO2-TPD was followed. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on the Themo ESClab 250xi instrument. The catalysts were reduced in situ with 99.99 % H2 prior to XPS analysis at 300 °C for 2 h. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalysts were tested in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor operated in trickle-flow mode. Approximately 1 mL catalyst was diluted with 24 grit carborundum in a 1:1 ratio. The catalyst was packed in the hottest zone of the reactor tube sandwiched by two layers of glass wool with carborundum packed on the opposite sides to prevent any temperature gradients in the reactor. The catalyst was reduced for 8 h with 99.99 % H2 flowing at 30 mL min−1 at 300 °C. The Bronkhorst mass-flow controllers were used to regulate the gas flow. Afterwards, the temperature was decreased to the reaction temperature (260 °C or 280 °C) under H2 flow. After the reaction temperature was reached, a 25 % CO2/H2 feed gas mixture was introduced, and the back-pressure regulator downstream of the reactor was adjusted to obtain a reaction pressure of 40 bar. After obtaining the desired pressure and temperature, 5 h was permitted for the reaction to reach steady state. The liquid and gas samples were collected every 6 h. The liquid sample as well as a gas sample were injected on the Shimadzu GC fitted with an FID detector, while another gas sample was injected on the HP 6890 series GC equipped with a TCD detector. Methanol and formic acid were the liquid products formed, while CO and CH4 were the gaseous products. Prepared methanol–water and formic acid–water standards were used for the calibration of the FID-GC. The following equations were used to calculate the CO2 conversion, selectivities and space-time yield: (3) C O 2 conversion ( % ) = [ C O 2 ] in − [ C O 2 ] out [ C O 2 ] in × 100 (4) Methanol selectivity ( % ) = [ C H 3 OH ] [ CO ] + [ C H 4 ] + [ C H 3 OH ] + [ HCOOH ] × 100 (5) Methanol STY ( g CH 3 OH k g catal . h ) = m CH 3 OH rt × m cat Where mCH3OH is the mass of methanol in the liquid product determined from the GC calibration of water–methanol mixtures. The term ‘rt’ is the reaction time, and mcat is the mass of the catalyst used during testing. [CO2]in, [CO2]out, [CH3OH], [CO], [CH4] and [HCOOH] refer to the corresponding concentrations of products and reactants in mols. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural properties Phase identification and crystallinity of the catalysts were evaluated with XRD, and the diffractograms are shown in Fig. 1 a. CeO2–S exhibited peaks arising from the cubic fluorite structure of ceria at 28.6 °, 33.1 °, 47.5 °, 56.3 °, 59.1 °, 69.4 °, 76.7 °, 79.1 ° 2θ [21,22]. When approximately 25 at.% of copper was introduced into the ceria matrix to form the Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ catalyst, the CeO2 fluorite structure was retained without any additional CuO peaks being observed. The absence of CuO peaks for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ could be rationalised to Cu2+cations (0.073 nm) with a smaller ionic radius than Ce4+ (0.094 nm) being substituted into the CeO2 lattice or CuO was finely dispersed with small crystallites over the surface of CeO2, making it difficult for the XRD instrument to detect. After introducing La, the cubic fluorite structure of ceria was retained for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, indicating that La3+ was also incorporated into the CeO2 lattice. However, increasing the La percentage further, for example, in the case of Cu0.25La0.375Ce0.375O2-δ, resulted in phase segregation as additional peaks due to La2O2CO3 at 29.6° and 44.6° 2θ were observed [23] and a small peak for CuO at 35.7° 2θ [24] was observed. There appears to be a modification of the fluorite structured of CeO2 for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, as the CeO2 peaks were hardly visible in the diffraction pattern. The formation of the La2CuO4 spinel was observed for Cu0.25La0.75Ox due to the strong interaction between Cu and La. The La2O2CO3 phase was formed through the reaction of La2O3 with atmospheric CO2 during catalyst synthesis [23] or possibly due to the formation of CO2 from urea during the combustion synthesis. CO2 is a by-product when urea is used as fuel during SCS [25]. Fig. 1b shows the XRD patterns of the used catalysts recovered after catalytic testing. The XRD patterns of the used catalysts are similar to the fresh catalyst, except for the appearance of peaks at 43.3 °, 50.5 ° and 74.3 ° 2θ representing metallic Cu. The XRD pattern of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ, for both the fresh and used catalysts (Fig. 1a and b), exhibited narrow and more intense peaks than CeO2-S, indicating larger crystallites for the former catalyst. However, with the addition and gradual increase in La loading, referring to Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, Cu0.25La0.375Ce0.375O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, peak broadening was observed, possibly suggesting that the presence of La favoured the formation of smaller crystallites, similar to what was reported by Liang et al. [26]. The crystallite size of CeO2 for the fresh and used catalysts were determined from the most intense CeO2 (111) peak at 28.6 ° from XRD, shown in Table 1 . The CeO2 crystallite size was observed to increase with the introduction of Cu (Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ), but, thereafter decreased with the subsequent increase of the amount of La, in agreement with the observed peak intensities from the XRD in Fig. 1a. The crystallite sizes of Cu° for the used catalysts are shown in Table 1. The metallic Cu crystallite size for Cu0.25La0.75Ox and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ could not be determined due to the low peak intensity in the XRD analysis for these two catalysts. The Cu° crystallite size of the used catalysts was the smallest for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ followed by Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ. The relatively small Cu° crystallite size for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ suggests that the interactions between Cu0 and the support were the most optimal for this catalyst. The CeO2 lattice constant (aCeO2) for the different catalysts is also shown in Table 1. Introducing Cu and La resulted in an increase in the CeO2 lattice constant from 5.411 for the synthesised ceria (CeO2-S) to 5.468 for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ. The expansion of the CeO2 lattice constant suggests that the larger La3+ (0.106 nm) replaced the smaller Ce4+ cation (0.094 nm) in the CeO2 lattice [27] to some extent or the number of defects sites associated with the presence of Ce3+ (0.114 nm), which is larger than Ce4+, increased [28]. Based on the observation that Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ showed a slightly larger lattice constant than CeO2-S, although the introduced Cu2+ cation is smaller (0.073 nm) than Ce4+ indicates that some defects associated with Ce3+, were most likely responsible for the lattice expansion. For catalysts containing both Cu and La, that is Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ and Cu0.25La0.375Ce0.375O2-δ, the increase in the CeO2 lattice constant could be a combination of Cu promoting the occurrence of Ce3+ and La3+ which are larger cations than Ce4+ , thus causing lattice expansion. If the smaller Cu2+ was being substituted into the CeO2 lattice, then an unchanged or smaller lattice constant for ceria is expected [29]. For the higher La containing catalysts, it is evident that besides any substitution in the ceria lattice, phase segregation will occur resulting in the La phases present either as La2O2CO3 or La2CuO4 as observed in Fig. 1a. The BET surface area results are given in Table 1. The surface area of CeO2 was relatively large in comparison to the Cu and La containing catalysts thus introducing Cu and La, caused a significant decrease in the surface area. It can be observed that the pore volume was relatively high for CeO2-S but decreased with the introduction of La and Cu, which may account for the decrease in surface area or having low porosity. Consistent with the decreasing surface area, the pore diameter increased due to the presence of Cu and La. An unorthodox trend observed for the catalysts was the decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size with the decreasing BET surface area. This peculiar trend has been previously observed with CuCeO2 catalysts, especially at higher concentrations of the dopant [16]. In Fig. 2 , the BET isotherms of the catalysts are shown where all catalysts are shown to exhibit a type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis, typical of mesoporous materials [30]. The Cu, Ce and La ICP-OES loadings are shown in Table 2 . Overall, there was a good correlation between the Ce and La nominal atomic loading with the actual at.% loading from ICP-OES. For example, a La or Cu nominal amount of 37.5 for Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ showed an ICP loading of 43 and 46 at.% for La and Ce which was close to the targeted ration of 1:1. Raman spectroscopy was carried out to investigate the structural features and defects of the catalysts, and the spectra are shown in Fig. 3 . For LaOx S, three bands were observed at 240, 375 and 1100 cm−1. The 240 cm−1 is attributed to La(OH)3 [31], while the bands at 375 cm−1 and 1100 cm−1 are related to the LaO2CO3 phase [23]. The CeO2-S spectra displayed a sharp F2g Raman band at 465 cm−1 related to the oxygen atoms surrounding the Ce4+ cation within the lattice [32,33]. As expected, decreasing the Ce content in the catalysts decreased the intensity of the F2g band up to the Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ catalyst. Thereafter, the F2g band increased, which could have been caused by exceeding the incorporation limit of La in the CeO2 lattice. For Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, a slight redshift of the F2g band was observed relative to Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ or CeO2-S. The F2g band shift indicates the formation of a CexLa1-xO2-δ solid solution [34]. The absence of La oxide peaks from the XRD, especially for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, supports this interpretation. A broad band centred at ∼ 600 cm−1 was observed for the Cu and La-doped catalysts, which was absent for CeO2 S. This band comprised of two overlapping bands (from peaks at 580 and 605 cm−1) arising from the contribution of the oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 lattice and MO8 complex (related to La), respectively [35]. The intensity ratio between the band at 580 cm−1 (D) and the F2g band (465 cm−1) (I580/I465) can give a reasonable estimation of defects associated with oxygen vacancies [36]. It is observed in Table 2 that the introduction of La resulted in the increase of the I580/I465 ratio from 0.32 for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ to 2.48 for Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ. Further increasing the La loading in the case of Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ caused a decrease in the I580/I465 ratio that might have been due to the partial modification of the CeO2 structure, as confirmed by the XRD in Fig. 1. Overall, the presence of La favoured the formation of oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 lattice due to the substitution of Ce4+ with La3+. HR-TEM was done to investigate the effect of increasing the La loading on the catalyst morphology, and the dark-field STEM images and corresponding elemental maps are shown in Fig. 4 a–c. There was a uniform distribution of all elements in the catalysts. However, Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, which showed some transformation of the CeO2 structure based on the XRD, does show a less homogenous distribution in Ce (see Fig. 4c). The bright-field HR-TEM images of the catalysts with lattice fringes are shown in Fig. 5 a–c. Lattice fringes associated with the CeO2 facets were observed for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ. However, for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, only lattice fringes corresponding to the La2O2CO3 phase can be seen, pointing to its abundance. The lattice expansion caused a slight shift in the d-spacings for CeO2 as the larger La3+ cation was substituted into the CeO2 lattice. Lattice fringes associated with CuO were observed, even for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, even though peaks associated with this phase were not present in the X-ray diffractograms, as observed in Fig. 1a. This suggests that the CuO crystallites were relatively small and, hence, below the detection limit of the XRD instrument. The H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 6 . The Cu-containing catalysts showed broad peaks between 100 and 300 °C. The asymmetric nature of the peaks suggested that they comprise smaller Gaussian peaks, shown in Fig. 6 after deconvolution. The first deconvoluted peak (α) in the temperature range of 100–300 °C was due to the reduction of finely dispersed CuO to metallic Cu0 [37,38], while the second peak (β) in this temperature range was ascribed to the reduction of bulk-like CuO [5,13] . The reduction of finely dispersed CuO to metallic Cu0 (α-peak) appeared as a shoulder to the left of the main peak in the 100–300 °C temperature range, especially for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ observed at a relatively lower temperature. When the La concentration was increased, the reduction of CuO shifted to higher temperatures. The shift to higher temperatures suggested that the presence of La made the CuO reduction difficult, indicating a significantly strong interaction between Cu and La. Furthermore, the La2CuO4 spinel phase, present in Cu0.25La0.75Ox, also likely contributed to the shift to higher temperatures for CuO reduction. On the contrary, for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ, the CuO reduction occurred at the lowest temperature of ca. 160 °C relative to the other catalysts. The H2-TPR results obtained suggest that CeO2 promoted the reduction of CuO while the La component had a strong interaction with CuO, hence making its reduction more difficult. A broad and shallow peak was observed for CeO2 S at ca. 500 °C attributed to the reduction of CeO2 to Ce2O3 [39,40]. The CeO2 reduction was not observed for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ. A peak occurring at 600 °C for LaOx-S was due to the reduction of the La2O2CO3 phase to La2O3 [41]. When the La amount was increased, in the case of Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, there was an increase in the peak area for La2O2CO3 reduction to La2O2CO3. The absence of the peak mentioned above for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ possibly suggests that the La2O2CO3 phase was not formed in this catalyst, or it existed in a relatively low concentration that was below the limit of detection of the H2-TPR instrument and hence any overlapping peaks could not be observed. Table 3 gives the hydrogen consumption data with respect to CuO reduction to metallic Cu0. It is observed that Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ showed the highest hydrogen consumption while Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ had the lowest. Based on the H2-TPR profile of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ in Fig. 6, this catalyst is expected to have a higher hydrogen consumption given its facile reduction deduced from the relatively low reduction temperature. Cu0.25La0.75Ox had the second-highest hydrogen consumption, although the reduction of this catalyst occurred at a relatively high temperature. This suggests that despite the formation of La2CuO4 spinel for Cu0.25La0.75Ox, the reduction of CuO, once initiated, proceeded with ease. The H2/Cu ratio was determined to provide insight into the extent of CuO reduction presented in Table 3. All the catalysts showed a high degree of CuO reduction based on the H2/Cu ratio in Table 3. The CO2-TPD profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The CeO2 S and Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ catalysts displayed peaks below 400 °C. For CeO2 S, the two peaks denoted ‘α’ and ‘β’ in Fig. 7 were attributed to weak and medium basic sites, respectively [42]. The above-mentioned basic sites were related to the surface OH- (weak basic sites) and metal–oxygen pairs (medium basic sites) [42]. Weak basic sites were only present in CeO2 S. However, medium basic sites (‘β’) were observed for CeO2 S and Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ. In addition, a peak denoted ‘γ’ was observed in the CO2-TPD profile of La-containing catalysts due to strong basic sites associated with the O2- species [43]. The peaks labelled ‘δ’, ‘δ/’ and ‘δ//’ in Fig. 7 were ascribed to the thermal decomposition of La2O2CO3 to form La oxide [44,45]. Based on the XRD pattern for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ in Fig. 1a and b, the La2O2CO3 phase was not observed for this catalyst. Therefore, the La2O2CO3 component detected from CO2-TPD was probably generated in-situ via the reaction of La containing species with the probe CO2 gas. The peaks assigned to La2O2CO3 decomposition (δ, δ/ and δ//) were visible in the CO2-TPD profiles of all the La-containing catalysts, which overlapped with the peaks ascribed to strong basic sites (‘γ’). For CeO2-S and Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ, the CO2 desorbed over medium basic sites (‘β’-peak) did not significantly change with the introduction of Cu. In Table 4 , the amount of CO2 desorbed over the different basic sites is shown. The quantity of medium basic sites increased slightly with the introduction of Cu, in reference to CeO2 S and Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ. Concerning the strong basic sites attributed to the La-containing catalysts, there appears to be a correlation between the amount of strong basic sites and the La loading, with the two variables being dependent. The only outlier in the trend between the amount of strong basic sites and the La loading was Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, which showed a relatively higher concentration of strong basic sites than Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ possibly caused by the higher BET surface area of the former (12 m2 g−1) versus 5 and 8 m2 g-1 for the latter two catalysts, respectively. The H2-TPD was carried out to investigate the hydrogen adsorption on the reduced catalysts, and the profiles are shown in Fig. 8 . CeO2 S did not show any peaks indicating that pure CeO2 was inefficient at adsorbing hydrogen. For Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, a peak was observed at ca. 650 °C that was due to the thermal decomposition of La2O2CO3 to La oxide [45]. The peak ascribed to metallic Cu was not observed, which could be rationalised by the low copper content in these catalysts. XPS of the H2 reduced Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ was done, and the spectra are represented in Fig. 9 a–d. The Cu 2p spectra for the two catalysts showed peaks at 932 and 952 eV attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively [46]. Satellite peaks synonymous with CuO at ca. 942 and 962 eV were not observed, confirming the absence of CuO. A slight shift to lower binding energies with La introduction suggests that electron transfer to Cu occurred. These results indicate that electron transfer from the electron-rich oxygen vacancies to Cu occurred. To further ascertain the oxidation state of Cu, the XPS Cu Auger peak was analysed and the Cu LMM spectra are shown in Fig. 10 . A more intense peak was observed at ca. 918.5 eV for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, which was related to metallic Cu [47]. However, for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, a tiny shoulder peak at 917.6 eV was visible, which was not present for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ. This additional peak was ascribed to Cu2O species [48]. Therefore, it would appear that the introduction of La facilitated the formation of Cu+ species, as similarly reported when La was added to Cu/SBA-15 [44]. In the Ce 3d spectra shown in Fig. 9b, peaks were denoted using the convention by Burroughs et al. [49]. After deconvolution, eight peaks were obtained due to Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2. The peaks denoted u, u’’, u’’’, v, v’’ and v’’’ were assigned to Ce4+ 3d, while those labelled u’ and v’ were attributed to Ce3+ 3d Furthermore, the peaks marked with v, v’, v’’ and v’’’ were related to the 3d3/2 state. The 3d5/2 was represented by the peaks u, u’, u’’ and u’’’ . The existence of the u’ and v’ peaks in the Ce 3d spectra for Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ indicates that Ce3+ was present, and this explains the lattice expansion of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ relative to CeO2-S shown in Table 2 as Ce3+ is larger than Ce4+. The presence of Ce3+ is significant because it indicates the presence of oxygen vacancies [50,51]. The La 3d5/2 spectrum for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ is shown in Fig. 9c. The 833.7 and 838.2 eV peaks are related to 3d5/2 cf0 and 3d5/2 cf1L bonding states, respectively [52]. The cf0 state (833.7 eV) does not involve charge transfer to the 4f orbital from the valence band, while for cf1L (838.2 eV) charge transfer occurred to the 4f orbital. The difference between the binding energy of the peaks cf1L and cf0 provides information on the phase of the La component [53]. The phases of La2O3, La(OH)3 and La2(CO3)3 have the doublet splitting energy (ΔE) values of 4.6, 3.9 and 3.5 eV, respectively [53,54]. In Fig. 9c, the ΔE value for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ was determined to be 4.5 eV which correlated to the La2O3 phase. According to the XRD results in Fig. 1a and b, the absence of La2O3 peaks suggests that the La component was combined with Ce to form the CexLa1−xO2-δ solid solution. Alternatively, a tiny amount of La2O3 might have been present, which was below the detection limit of the XRD instrument. The O 1s spectra for the reduced Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ are represented in Fig. 9d. The deconvoluted peaks denoted α and β in the O 1s spectrum of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ are assigned to lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies, respectively [55]. Based on the appearance, the intensity of the β-peak related to oxygen vacancies was high relative to that of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ, suggesting that La increased the concentration of oxygen vacancies, which concurred with the I580/I465 ratio used to estimate the amount of oxygen vacancies in Table 2. The XPS spectra of unreduced Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ, Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ and Cu0.25La0.75Ox are shown in Fig. 11 a–d. The Cu 2p spectra exhibited strong shake-up satellite peaks at 942 and 962 eV, indicating the presence of CuO [46]. The Cu 2p3/2 peak was further deconvoluted to produce two peaks labelled h.d Cu2+ and s.i Cu2+ in Fig. 11a. The h.d Cu2+ referred to highly dispersed Cu2+ and s. i Cu2+ is related Cu2+ interacting strongly with the support [56]. The catalysts with both La and Ce (Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ) had a small amount of strongly interacting Cu2+ species with the support when compared to Cu0.25La0.75Ox based on peak intensity (Fig. 11a). This suggests that the interaction of Ce and La was significant in improving the concentration of finely dispersed Cu species. The same notation, which was used to label peaks for the La 3d spectra in Fig. 9c, was applied in Fig. 11b. The only exception is the inclusion of the 3d3/2 peak occurring at ca. 852 eV, which is due to the 3d3/2 cf0 representing La3+[52]. The same notation was used for labelling the Ce 3d spectrum in Fig. 11c, as discussed in detail in Fig. 9b. Lastly, the O 1s spectra of the unreduced catalysts in Fig. 11d showed similar peaks to the O 1s spectra for the reduced catalysts in Fig. 9d with an analogous discussion. Table 5 presents the results of Cu surface composition, the fraction of Ce3+, oxygen vacancy concentration (Oβ/Ototal) for the reduced catalysts and ΔE from the La 3d spectra. The Cu surface composition decreased with the increase in La loading. The amount of Ce3+ was the highest for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, coinciding with the complete incorporation of La in the CeO2 lattice. These results suggest that the proximity between La and Ce was crucial for the generation of Ce3+ species that are associated with oxygen vacancies. The concentration of oxygen vacancies (Oβ/Ototal) was higher for the pre-reduced Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ catalyst (0.40) compared to pre-reduced Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ (0.27), as shown in Table 5. The results in Table 5 indicate that incorporating La into the lattice of ceria to form CexLa1−xO2-δ resulted in the creation of oxygen vacancies to compensate for the decrease in the positive charge, thus maintaining electroneutrality. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between the concentration of Ce3+ and the Oβ/Ototal ratio representing the concentration of oxygen vacancies. The ΔE from the La 3d spectra showed that Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ had the optimum amount of La that could be incorporated entirely into the CeO2 lattice supported by the absence of the La2O2CO3 phase formed by excess La species on the catalyst surface for the fresh catalyst. The ΔE from the La 3d spectra of the used catalysts is also shown in Table 5. All the La-containing catalysts exhibited ΔE values ranging from 3.4 to 3.6 eV, characteristic of La2(CO3)3. However, the absence of peaks for the La2O2CO3 phase in the XRD of the used Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ catalyst in Fig. 1b suggests that the ΔE is comparable to that of structural La2(CO3)3 which might have been due to adsorbed carbonates interacting with La. 3.2 Catalytic results The catalysts were evaluated for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol to form methanol, carbon monoxide, methane, and formic acid. Both methane and formic acid were the minor products with selectivities of < 1 %. In the following discussion of the catalytic results, the minor products will not be considered. 3.2.1 Effect of Ce to La ratio and reaction temperature on catalytic performance In Fig. 12 a–d, the performance of the catalysts as a function of the reaction temperature is shown. At a temperature of 260 °C the CO2 conversion decreased in the order: Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ > Cu0.25La0.75Ox ≈ Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ ≈ Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ. The highest CO2 conversion of 6.5 % was obtained at the reaction temperature of 260 °C for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ as shown in Fig. 12a. Increasing the reaction temperature from 260 °C to 280 °C resulted in the rearrangement of the CO2 conversion trend which decreased in the order: Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ > Cu0.25La0.75Ox > Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ. Notably, at the temperature of 280 °C Cu0.25La0.75Ox, Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ had similar CO2 conversions of ca. 6 %. In contrast to the CO2 conversion obtained at 260 °C, Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ showed the highest conversion of ∼10 % at 280 °C. The higher CO2 conversion of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ at 280 °C was likely due to the relatively high BET surface area of 15 m2 g-1 compared to 4–11 m2 g−1 for other catalysts. In addition, this catalyst also exhibited the highest hydrogen consumption in H2-TPR of 24.1 mmol g−1 as shown in Table 3, suggesting an abundance of catalytic sites for H2 adsorption and dissociation, which thus explains the higher CO2 conversion. The methanol selectivity at the temperature of 260 °C in Fig. 12b decreased in the order: Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ > Cu0.25La0.75Ox > Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ. The highest methanol selectivity of 90 % was obtained over Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ. The methanol selectivity appeared to increase with the La loading suggesting that the introduced dopant benefited the methanol selectivity. Notably, Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25La0.75Ox showed a lower methanol selectivity. In contrast, CO selectivity was high for these catalysts, compared to the Ce and La-containing catalysts, suggesting a synergistic interaction between the two rare-earth metals favoured methanol formation. Similarly, to the CO2 conversion, increasing the reaction temperature to 280 °C from 260 °C changed the trend of methanol selectivity, with Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ showing a slightly higher methanol selectivity than Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ. At the reaction temperature of 280 °C, Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ and Cu0.25La0.75Ox maintained a relatively low methanol selectivity compared to other catalysts. This suggests that any synergistic relationship between Ce and La that benefited methanol selectivity at 260 °C was retained with an increase in reaction temperature. Increasing the reaction temperature from 260 °C to 280 °C decreased the methanol selectivity for all the catalysts due to the exothermicity of the methanol synthesis reaction. The formation of CO, through the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction competes with methanol formation. The water, that is also produced, can lead to a loss in activity due to Cu sintering [57]. It was found that CO selectivity at 260 °C decreased in the order: Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ > Cu0.25La0.75Ox > Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ > Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ as shown in Fig. 12c. The CO selectivity trend was opposite to that of methanol selectivity at 260 °C as the methanol formation proceeded in parallel to the RWGS reaction with negligible contribution from side reactions such as the formation of methane and formic acid. Increasing the La loading had an inhibitory effect on CO formation thus favouring a higher selectivity to methanol. The methanol space-time yield (STY) data are shown in Fig. 12d, and it was observed that methanol STY showed a general increase with an increase in La loading for the CeLa containing catalysts except for Cu0.25Ce0.375La0.375O2-δ. The maximum methanol STY of 33.1 gCH3OH .kgcatal −1.h−1 was obtained for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ at 260 °C. Considering that STY is dependent on conversion and selectivity, the trend observed at 260 °C changed at the higher temperature. The reasoning for the observed trend could be due to the dynamic nature of the active species that were affected by the reaction temperature. Firstly, Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ did not show the presence of the La2O2CO3 phase based on the XRD and XPS analysis in Fig. 1a and b and Fig. 9c, respectively. Chen et al. [6] established that the Cu/La2O2CO3 catalyst was highly active for methanol production from CO2 hydrogenation. In contrast to Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ, the La-rich catalyst (Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ) showed the presence of the La2O2CO3 phase, according to the HRTEM results. The methanol STY results surmised that at relatively lower temperatures (260 °C) the La2O2CO3 species had a significant contribution to the catalytic performance greater than that of the CexLa1−xO2-δ solid solution. However, based on the XRD data, which show an abundance of the La2O2CO3 phase for the CuLa catalyst (Cu0.25La0.75Ox,) it does explain the poorer yield for this catalyst compared to the CuCeLa catalyst. This would suggest a beneficial relationship between the ceria and La2O2CO3. However, this relationship was less favoured at the higher temperature since Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ now showed a better yield, and since it was rich in the CexLa1-xO2-δ solid solution, it suggests that the solid solution was more active at the higher temperature. 3.2.2 Influence of La on the catalytic performance The performance of the catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction is known to be influenced by specific physicochemical properties of the catalyst, such as Cu surface area [17,58], particle size [59,60] and basicity [61,62]. The assessment of the impact of La introduction on the above-mentioned structural properties for the CuCeO2 catalyst and how these properties correlate to the catalytic performance is of interest. The Cu composition from XPS analysis gives a measure of the catalytically active Cu species. There is a correlation between the surface Cu composition and the CO2 conversion, according to the results shown in Fig. 13 . However, increasing the La content did not benefit the Cu surface composition. These results suggest that the adsorption of H2 on Cu was not the primary descriptor for methanol production. According to a review by Kattel et al. [63], the metal-metal oxide interface is the active site for methanol synthesis for CO2 hydrogenation. In the current study, a decreasing crystallite size of CeO2 improved the catalytic performance as the number of metal-metal oxide interfacial sites increased, agreeing well with the perspective of Kattel et al. [63]. In the current study, the interface is formed by Cu0 or Cu+ and either CexLa1−xO2-δ solid solution or La2O2CO3. The relationship between the CeO2 crystallite size and the methanol selectivity with an increase in the La content was assessed. An inverse relationship between the CeO2 crystallite size and the methanol selectivity was observed, as shown in Fig. 14 . Increasing the La loading caused a decrease in the CeO2 crystallite size while the methanol selectivity increased. Therefore, the results in Fig. 14 partly concur with those of Kattel et al. [63], and the interface was crucial for methanol production. In CO2 hydrogenation reactions, there is a consensus in the literature that oxygen vacancies are crucial for the initial CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface [64,65]. The presence of Ce3+ in a catalyst indicates the presence of oxygen vacancies as these are formed to maintain electroneutrality [66]. The correlation between Ce3+ and the methanol space-time yield was investigated, and the results are presented in Fig. 15 . There was a positive correlation between Ce3+ and the methanol space-time yield. However, Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ appears to be an outlier. This could suggest that the dominant active site for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ differed from the other catalysts. Based on the results in Fig. 15, the oxygen vacancies associated with Ce3+ actively catalysed methanol formation acting as adsorption sites for CO2 which consecutively reacted with H2 adsorbed on the adjacent Cu particles to produce methanol. Comparing the data from catalyst characterisation and the catalytic results discussed thus far, the nature of the active centres for methanol synthesis is proposed. The La-lean (Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ) and La-rich (Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ) catalysts were used as descriptors to explain the nature of the active species. Firstly, the XRD (Fig. 1a), lattice fringes from HRTEM (Fig. 5) and XPS results (Figs. 9 and 11) all confirmed the presence of the La2O2CO3 on the surface of Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ, and this phase was absent in Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ. The latter (Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ) was comprised of the CexLa1-xO2-δ solid solution with Cu supported over it according to the XRD and HRTEM lattice fringe data in Figs. 1a and 5b, respectively. However, Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ consisted of the CexLa1-xO2-δ solid solution and La2O2CO3 with Cu on the surface. Furthermore, the XPS results indicated that the CexLa1-xO2-δ solid solution was rich in oxygen vacancies, as supported by the presence of Ce3+based on the XPS results in Fig. 9. The oxygen vacancies were catalytically active for methanol formation from CO2 (Fig. 15). Based on the study by Chen et al. [6], Cu/La2O2CO3 is highly active for methanol production from CO2. Therefore, two types of active catalytic centres catalysed the reaction, Cu/La2O2CO3 from excess La on the surface and Cu/CexLa1−xO2-δ for the La-rich catalyst (Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ). However, for the La-lean catalyst (Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ) only the Cu/CexLa1−xO2-δ active domain facilitated the reaction. The catalytic results in Fig. 12 showed a relatively higher methanol STY of 33.1 gCH3OH.kgcatal −1.h−1 for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ compared to 25.4 gCH3OH.kgcatal.h−1 for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ at the reaction temperature of 260 °C. This suggests that the two catalytic active centres (Cu/La2O2CO3 and Cu/CexLa1−xO2-δ) operated synergistically to elevate the performance of Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ. Moreover, based on Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ being an outlier in Fig. 15, where a correlation between Ce3+associated with oxygen vacancies and methanol STY was illustrated, suggests that the Cu/La2O2CO3 was the dominant catalytic site for methanol formation over this catalyst. On the contrary, Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ with only the Cu/CexLa1−xO2-δ active centre showed a relatively poorer performance at 260 °C. When the reaction temperature was increased to 280 °C, Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ now showed a relatively lower methanol STY of 28.1 gCH3OH.kgcatal.h−1 compared to Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ with a methanol STY of 32.5 gCH3OH.kgcatal −1.h−1. Consequently, the oxygen vacancy-rich Cu/CexLa1−xO2-δ centres were more active at higher reaction temperatures (280 °C) than at lower temperatures (260 °C), while the Cu/La2O2CO3 active centre became less active at higher temperatures. The reason for the lower methanol STY of Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ at the reaction temperature of 280 °C is perhaps caused by the transformation of La2O2CO3 to the less-active hydrocarbonate while generating water in the process as reported by Chen et al. [6]. Furthermore, the excess water generated could have hindered the reaction by inducing Cu crystallisation. Regarding the reaction mechanism, Wang et al. [5]] observed that monodentate and bidentate carbonates were formed over coordinatively unsaturated O2-related oxygen vacancies upon CO2 adsorption on Cu/CeO2 when probed by in situ DRIFT. The carbonate intermediate reacted with atomic hydrogen adsorbed on Cu to produce the formate, and further hydrogenated to methanol. The *HCOO (formate) species was reported to be the only observable intermediate after CO2 adsorption on Cu/La2O2CO3 catalysts in the DRFT experiment [6]. The XRD of the used catalysts showed peaks of metallic copper in Fig. 1b. However, the Cu LMM spectra of reduced Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ (Fig. 10) revealed the presence of Cu+1, which was not present in Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ. Based on the methanol productivity of Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ, despite the lack of Cu1+, suggests that the metallic Cu0 was responsible for H2 dissociation to atomic hydrogen. Further, in-situ studies are necessary to ascertain the contribution of Cu1+ to the catalytic performance. Lastly, given the reports mentioned above on the intermediates involved in catalytic systems similar to the current study, the formate mechanism was the most likely pathway followed by the investigated catalysts. However, the contribution of other mechanisms, such as the reverse water-gas shift coupled with methanol formation, cannot be completely ruled out. 3.2.3 Effect of GHSV on the catalytic performance Considering that the Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ catalyst showed the best activity at 280 °C, some optimisation was done regarding changing the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) and pressure. The influence of the GHSV on the activity is shown in Fig. 16 a and b. Methanol selectivity, which was 78 % at the GHSV of 1350 h−1, decreased to 58.1 % when the GHSV was increased to 2700 h-1, while at the same time, CO selectivity increased from 21.6 % to 41.1 %. The relationship between the methanol and CO selectivity with the variation of the space velocity could indicate that, CO formed via the RWGS, was then involved in methanol formation. When the GHSV was increased, CO was desorbed to the gas phase instead of reacting further to produce methanol due to a shorter contact time on the catalyst surface, which decreased methanol selectivity. Similarly to methanol selectivity, CO2 conversion and methanol STY were suppressed when the GHSV was increased from 1350 h−1 to 2700 h−1, as presented in Fig. 16b. 3.2.4 Effect of reaction pressure on the catalytic performance Methanol synthesis is pressure sensitive. Therefore, the pressure of the reactants (CO2 and H2) influences the direction of the equilibrium according to Le Chatelier's principle. In Fig. 17 a, methanol selectivity was observed to increase from 78 % to 87 % with an increase in the reaction pressure from 40 to 50 bar, while at the same time, CO selectivity decreased from 21.6 % to 13.1 %. The CO2 conversion (Fig. 17b) was approximately 9 % at 40 bar but increased to 11.1 % with an increase in reaction pressure to 50 bar. Similarly, as expected, increasing the reaction pressure from 40 to 50 bar significantly improved the methanol STY from 32.5 gCH3OH .kgcatal −1 .h-1 to 55.2 gCH3OH .kgcatal −1 .h−1. 3.2.5 Performance comparison of CuCeLa catalysts only Since the catalysts containing all three metals (Cu, Ce and La) were structurally different to Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ or Cu0.25La0.75Ox, a comparison of the performance of the bimetallic supported catalysts was done in relation to key structural parameters, as presented in Fig. 18 a–c. Firstly, the influence of hydrogen consumption from H2-TPR on the CO2 conversion was demonstrated in Fig. 18a. The CO2 conversion increased with the hydrogen consumption, signifying that more active sites for H2 adsorption and dissociation were present. The Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ catalyst showed the highest hydrogen consumption and CO2 conversion, suggesting that the La loading of ≤ 0.19 at.% promoted the amount of Cu catalytic sites that facilitated hydrogen adsorption and dissociation. Fig. 18b illustrates the relationship between Ce3+ and the CO2 conversion. As previously mentioned, Ce3+ indicates oxygen vacancies in the lattice. Therefore, an increase in Ce3+ suggests that the number of oxygen vacancies also increased. An increasing Ce3+ concentration corresponded to an increase in CO2 conversion. This suggests that oxygen vacancies were catalytic sites for CO2 adsorption and conversion to products such as methanol and CO. Fig. 18c reiterates the above statement as the methanol space-time yield increased with the total basicity which followed the same trend as the Ce3+concentration (indicating oxygen vacancies). Overall, Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ performed the best because of its high amount of Cu catalytic sites for H2 adsorption and abundance of oxygen vacancies for CO2 adsorption. The HR-TEM images of the spent catalysts of interest, namely Cu0.25Ce0.75O2-δ, Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ and Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ did not exhibit any significant particle agglomeration, as illustrated by Fig. 19 a–c. Furthermore, the time on stream for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ is presented in Fig. 20 . Based on the time-on-stream results, there was no deactivation of the catalytic sites for a period of 24 h of catalytic testing, suggesting that the CuCeLa catalysts were highly stable under the used reaction conditions. The best-performing catalyst (Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ) was compared with those reported in the literature below. In Table 6 , it is observed that the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity of 11.1 % and 87 % obtained for Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ under optimum reaction conditions were close to those results reported for LaCr0.5Cu0.5O3 (methanol selectivity and CO2 conversion of 75.6 % and 12.1 %) and La0.8Ce0.2Cu0.7Zn0.3Ox (methanol selectivity and CO2 conversion of 52.5 % and 12.6 %). 4 Conclusion The performance of La-incorporated CuCeO2 catalysts was investigated in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The highest CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity and space-time yield of 11.1 %, 87 % and 55.2 gCH3OH.kgcat −1.h−1 were obtained over the Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ catalyst at the temperature, pressure and GHSV of 280 °C, 50 bar and 1350 h−1, respectively. The introduction of La promoted the formation of smaller ceria crystallites in the catalysts, improving the number of interfacial sites crucial for the adsorption of CO2, which then reacted with H2 activated over Cu0. A La composition of 19 at% was optimal for complete incorporation into the ceria lattice, forming the oxygen vacancy-rich Cux/CeyLa1-( x + y )O2-δ active domains that showed excellent catalytic performance at higher reaction temperatures. Above the La loading of 19 at%, excess La created an additional Cu/La2O2CO3 catalytic active centre that further enhanced the reactivity. The improvement in the catalytic performance with a decrease in the GHSV suggests that the CO intermediate preferentially reacted further with H2 to methanol instead of desorbing to the gas phase. coredata.dc:description: The effect of La incorporation on the catalytic performance of Cu–CeO2 for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was investigated. The increase of the CeO2 lattice constant and shift in the F2g band from Raman spectroscopy confirmed La incorporation into the CeO2 lattice. The La atomic percent of ≤ 19 % was the upper limit for the amount of La incorporated fully into the CeO2 lattice without any phase segregation. XPS results of Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ assumed to have full La incorporation, showed a maximum concentration of oxygen vacancies that facilitated CO2 adsorption and conversion to methanol. The lattice fringes from HRTEM and lattice expansion confirmed that Cu was located on the catalyst surface for the synthesized catalysts. Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ showed an improvement in the methanol space-time yield when the temperature was increased from 260 °C to 280 °C, in contrast to the catalysts with excess La on the surface. The descriptors for the methanol production were the availability of oxygen vacancies and the metal-metal oxide interaction (Cu–CexLa1−xO2-δ and Cu–La2O2CO3). The smaller metallic Cu crystallite size for Cu0.25Ce0.19La0.56O2-δ suggested increased interactions between Cu0 and the CexLa1−xO2-δ support, which was conducive for methanol formation. The highest performance of Cu0.25Ce0.56La0.19O2-δ at a higher temperature of 280 °C and pressure of 50 bar with a methanol space-time yield of 55.2 gCH3OH.kgcatal.h−1 was attributed to the excellent thermal stability of the formed CexLa1−xO2-δ solid solution support interacting with Cu which prevented sintering.
